message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: An Introduction to Lorenzen's ‘Algebraic and Logistic Investigations on Free Lattices’ (1951)
Paper Abstract: This article proposes an historical and mathematical introduction to Lorenzen's Algebraische und logistische Untersuchungen uber freie Verbande. These Investigations appeared in 1951 in The journal of symbolic logic. They have immediately been recognised as a landmark in the history of infinitary proof theory, but their approach and method of proof have not been incorporated into the corpus of proof theory. More precisely, the admissibility of cut is proved by double induction, on the cut formula and on the complexity of the derivations, without using any ordinal assignment, contrary to the presentation of cut elimination in most standard texts on proof theory. 
We propose a translation (arXiv:1710.08138) and this introduction with the intent of giving a new impetus to their reception. We also propose a translation of a preliminary manuscript, A preorder-theoretic proof of consistency, with the kind permission of Lorenzen's daughter, Jutta Reinhardt. 
The Investigations are best known for providing a constructive proof of consistency for ramified type theory without axiom of reducibility. Lorenzen does so by showing that it is a part of a trivially consistent calculus that describes our knowledge of arithmetic without detour. The proof resorts only to the inductive definition of formulas and theorems. He proposes furthermore a definition of a semilattice, of a distributive lattice, of a pseudocomplemented semilattice, and of a countably complete boolean lattice as deductive calculuses, and shows how to present them for constructing the respective free object over a given preordered set. This work illustrates that lattice theory is a bridge between algebra and logic. 
The preliminary manuscript, given as an appendix, contains already the main ideas and applies them to a constructive proof of consistency for elementary number theory.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what elementary number theory is:

## Definition

Elementary number theory studies aspects of integers that can be investigated using elementary methods such as elementary proofs. More specifically, elementary number theory deals with the topics in number theory by means of basic methods in arithmetic, with its primary subjects of study being divisibility, factorization, and primality, as well as congruences in modular arithmetic.

## Key Topics

Other topics in elementary number theory include Diophantine equations, continued fractions, integer partitions, and Diophantine approximations.

## Educational Level

Elementary number theory includes topics of number theory commonly taught at the primary and secondary school level, or in college courses on introductory number theory.

## Historical Context

Euclid devoted part of his Elements to topics that belong to elementary number theory, including prime numbers and divisibility, and he gave the Euclidean algorithm for computing the greatest common divisor of two numbers and a proof implying the infinitude of primes.

Links: [{"title":"Semilattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semilattice"},{"title":"Complete lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_lattice"},{"title":"Maximal semilattice quotient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximal_semilattice_quotient"},{"title":"Lattice (order) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(order)"},{"title":"Join and meet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Join_and_meet"},{"title":"Free lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_lattice"},{"title":"Semigroup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semigroup"},{"title":"Congruence lattice problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congruence_Lattice_Problem"},{"title":"Monoid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monoid"},{"title":"Arrangement of hyperplanes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arrangement_of_hyperplanes"}]

## Semilattice in Mathematics

A semilattice is an important algebraic structure in mathematics with applications in order theory and abstract algebra.

### Definition

A join-semilattice (or upper semilattice) is a partially ordered set that has a join (a least upper bound) for any nonempty finite subset.(no content)Dually, a meet-semilattice (or lower semilattice) is a partially ordered set which has a meet (or greatest lower bound) for any nonempty finite subset.

### Algebraic Properties

A semilattice is a commutative, idempotent semigroup; i.e., a commutative band. Additionally, a bounded semilattice is an idempotent commutative monoid.

### Order-Theoretic Characterization

A partial order is induced on a meet-semilattice by setting x ≤ y whenever x ∧ y = x. For a join-semilattice, the order is induced by setting x ≤ y whenever x ∨ y = y.

### Related Structures

Semilattices include lattices, which in turn include Heyting and Boolean algebras. Semilattices also appear in various applications, such as face semilattices of hyperplane arrangements, where the face semilattice is the set of all faces ordered by inclusion, and adding an extra top element gives the face lattice.

Based on the search results, here's information about preorders in mathematics:

## Definition

A preorder or quasiorder is a binary relation that is reflexive and transitive.(no content)The name preorder is meant to suggest that preorders are almost partial orders, but not quite, as they are not necessarily antisymmetric.

## Characteristics

A preorder can be visualized as a directed graph, with elements of the set corresponding to vertices, and the order relation between pairs of elements corresponding to the directed edges between vertices. An important feature of preorders is that a preorder that is symmetric is an equivalence relation.

## Related Concepts

- A preorder that is antisymmetric no longer has cycles; it is a partial order, and corresponds to a directed acyclic graph.

- In mathematics, a directed set (or a directed preorder or a filtered set) is a preordered set in which every finite subset has an upper bound.

- A total preorder or weak order is a preorder in which any two elements are comparable.

## Applications

Preorders appear in various areas of mathematics, including topology, where the specialization preorder is a natural preorder on the set of the points of a topological space and, for spaces satisfying the T0 separation axiom, this preorder is a partial order.

Based on the search results, here's information about preorders in mathematics:

## Definition

A preorder or quasiorder is a binary relation that is reflexive and transitive.(no content)The name preorder is meant to suggest that preorders are almost partial orders, but not quite, as they are not necessarily antisymmetric.

## Characteristics

A preorder can be visualized as a directed graph, with elements of the set corresponding to vertices, and the order relation between pairs of elements corresponding to the directed edges between vertices. An important feature of preorders is that a preorder that is symmetric is an equivalence relation.

## Related Concepts

- A preorder that is antisymmetric no longer has cycles; it is a partial order, and corresponds to a directed acyclic graph.

- In mathematics, a directed set (or a directed preorder or a filtered set) is a preordered set in which every finite subset has an upper bound.

- A total preorder or weak order is a preorder in which any two elements are comparable.

## Applications

Preorders appear in various areas of mathematics, including topology, where the specialization preorder is a natural preorder on the set of the points of a topological space and, for spaces satisfying the T0 separation axiom, this preorder is a partial order.

Web search results for query: "cut elimination"

Links: [{"title":"Cut-elimination theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cut-elimination_theorem"},{"title":"Cut rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cut_rule"},{"title":"Talk:Cut-elimination theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Cut-elimination_theorem"},{"title":"Takeuti's conjecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Takeuti's_conjecture"},{"title":"Natural deduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_deduction"},{"title":"Modus ponens - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Implication_elimination"},{"title":"Shear Genius season 2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shear_Genius_(Season_2)"},{"title":"The Cut (2005 TV series) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Cut_(2005_TV_series)"},{"title":"Elimination from postseason contention - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elimination_from_postseason_contention"},{"title":"Shear Genius season 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shear_Genius_season_1"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about **cut elimination**:

## Cut Elimination in Logic and Proof Theory

The cut-elimination theorem states that any sequent that possesses a proof in the sequent calculus making use of the cut rule also possesses a cut-free proof, that is, a proof that does not make use of the cut rule.

### What is the Cut Rule?

The meaning of the cut rule is that, if a formula A appears as a conclusion in one proof and a hypothesis in another, then another proof in which the formula A does not appear can be deduced.

### Importance and Applications

Once a system is shown to have a cut elimination theorem, it is normally immediate that the system is consistent. Additionally, cut elimination is one of the most powerful tools for proving interpolation theorems.(no content)In most well behaved logics, cut is unnecessary as an inference rule, though it remains provable as a meta-theorem; the superfluousness of the cut rule is usually presented as a computational process, known as cut elimination.

### Historical Note

Takeuti's conjecture is the conjecture of Gaisi Takeuti that a sequent formalisation of second-order logic has cut-elimination.

Cut elimination is a fundamental concept in mathematical logic and proof theory with significant implications for understanding the structure of formal logical systems.

Links: [{"title":"Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"Category:Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"Residuated Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Residuated_Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"Free Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"Boolean algebra (structure) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_algebra_(structure)"},{"title":"Complete Boolean algebra - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_Boolean_algebra"},{"title":"List of Boolean algebra topics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Boolean_algebra_topics"},{"title":"Inclusion (Boolean algebra) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusion_(Boolean_algebra)"},{"title":"Boolean matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_matrix"},{"title":"Boolean-valued model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean-valued_model"}]

## Boolean Algebra

Boolean algebra is a branch of algebra in mathematics and mathematical logic.(no content)It differs from elementary algebra in that the values of variables are truth values true and false, usually denoted by 1 and 0, whereas in elementary algebra the values are numbers.

### Basic Structure

A Boolean algebra is a set equipped with two binary operations ∧ (called "meet" or "and") and ∨ (called "join" or "or"), a unary operation ¬ (called "complement" or "not"), and two elements 0 and 1 (called "bottom" and "top").

### Applications and Significance

Boolean algebra has been fundamental in the development of digital electronics and is provided for in all modern programming languages.(no content)It is also used in set theory and statistics.(no content)The two-element Boolean algebra has applications in logic, interpreting 0 as false, 1 as true, ∧ as and, ∨ as or, and ¬ as not.(no content)It is also used for circuit design in electrical engineering, where 0 and 1 represent the two different states of one bit in a digital circuit.

### Historical Background

The term honors George Boole (1815–1864), an English mathematician who introduced the algebraic system in 1847 and published a more substantial work in 1854.(no content)In the 1930s, Claude Shannon observed that Boole's algebra could be applied to switching circuits and introduced switching algebra for circuit analysis and design.

Links: [{"title":"Mathematical induction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_induction"},{"title":"Structural induction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_induction"},{"title":"Talk:Three forms of mathematical induction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Three_forms_of_mathematical_induction"},{"title":"Mathematics and Plausible Reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics_and_Plausible_Reasoning"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Mathematics/Archive/2006/Mar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:WikiProject_Mathematics/Archive11"},{"title":"Mathematics in the medieval Islamic world - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_mathematics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about mathematical induction:

## Definition and Basic Structure

Mathematical induction infers that a statement involving a natural number n holds for all values of n. The proof consists of two steps: The base case (or initial case): prove that the statement holds for 0, or 1.(no content)The induction step requires proving that for every n, if the statement holds for n, then it holds for n + 1. In other words, one assumes that the statement holds for some arbitrary natural number n, and proves that the statement holds for n + 1.

## Key Characteristics

Mathematical induction differs fundamentally from inductive reasoning as used in philosophy, in which the examination of many cases results in a probable conclusion. The mathematical method examines infinitely many cases to prove a general statement, but it does so by a finite chain of deductive reasoning involving the variable n, which can take infinitely many values.(no content)Mathematical induction is an inference rule used in formal proofs, and is the foundation of most correctness proofs for computer programs.

## Historical Development

The earliest implicit proof by mathematical induction was written by al-Karaji around 1000 AD, who applied it to arithmetic sequences to prove the binomial theorem.(no content)The first explicit formulation of the principle of induction was given by Pascal in his Traité du triangle arithmétique (1665).(no content)The modern formal treatment of the principle came only in the 19th century, with George Boole, Augustus De Morgan, Charles Sanders Peirce, Giuseppe Peano, and Richard Dedekind.

The mathematical method examines infinitely many cases to prove a general statement, but it does so by a finite chain of deductive reasoning involving the variable n, which can take infinitely many values.(no content)Mathematical induction is an inference rule used in formal proofs, and is the foundation of most correctness proofs for computer programs.

## Historical Development

The earliest implicit proof by mathematical induction was written by al-Karaji around 1000 AD, who applied it to arithmetic sequences to prove the binomial theorem.(no content)The first explicit formulation of the principle of induction was given by Pascal in his Traité du triangle arithmétique (1665).(no content)The modern formal treatment of the principle came only in the 19th century, with George Boole, Augustus De Morgan, Charles Sanders Peirce, Giuseppe Peano, and Richard Dedekind.

## Definition and Basic Structure

Mathematical induction infers that a statement involving a natural number n holds for all values of n. The proof consists of two steps: The base case (or initial case): prove that the statement holds for 0, or 1.(no content)The induction step requires proving that for every n, if the statement holds for n, then it holds for n + 1. In other words, one assumes that the statement holds for some arbitrary natural number n, and proves that the statement holds for n + 1.

Based on the search results, here's information about free lattices in mathematics:

## Definition

In mathematics, in the area of order theory, a free lattice is the free object corresponding to a lattice.(no content)As free objects, they have the universal property.(no content)The category of all lattices constitute a variety (universal algebra), and thus there exist (by general principles of universal algebra) free objects within this category: lattices where only those relations hold which follow from the general axioms.

## Key Properties

One of the most remarkable properties of free lattices is their growth: The free lattice of a three-element set of generators is infinite. Even more remarkably, every free lattice on three generators contains a sublattice which is free for a set of four generators. By induction, this eventually yields a sublattice free on countably many generators.

## The Word Problem

The word problem for free lattices has some interesting aspects. The word problem for free bounded lattices is the problem of determining which of these elements of W(X) denote the same element in the free bounded lattice FX, and hence in every bounded lattice.(no content)One may then show that the partially ordered quotient space W(X)/~ is the free bounded lattice FX.

## Complete Free Lattices

The complete free lattice (on three or more generators) "does not exist", in the sense that it is a proper class.

Links: [{"title":"Type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_theory"},{"title":"Intuitionistic type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intuitionistic_type_theory"},{"title":"Kind (type theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kind_(type_theory)"},{"title":"Container (type theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Container_(type_theory)"},{"title":"Homotopy type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homotopy_type_theory"},{"title":"Type A and Type B personality theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_A_and_Type_B_personality_theory"},{"title":"History of type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_type_theory"},{"title":"List of types of systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_types_of_systems_theory"},{"title":"Polynomial functor (type theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynomial_functor_(type_theory)"},{"title":"Category:Type theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Type_theory"}]

Here are the search results for "type theory":

## Overview

Type theory refers to a typed system based around lambda calculus.(no content)A type theory is a mathematical logic, which is to say it is a collection of rules of inference that result in judgments.

## Historical Development

Type theory was initially created to avoid paradoxes in a variety of formal logics and rewrite systems. Later, type theory referred to a class of formal systems, some of which can serve as alternatives to naive set theory as a foundation for all mathematics.(no content)By 1908, Russell arrived at a ramified theory of types together with an axiom of reducibility. This system avoided contradictions suggested in Russell's paradox by creating a hierarchy of types and then assigning each concrete mathematical entity to a specific type.

## Modern Applications

One influential system is Per Martin-Löf's intuitionistic type theory, which was proposed as a foundation for constructive mathematics.(no content)Another is Thierry Coquand's calculus of constructions, which is used as the foundation by Rocq (previously known as Coq), Lean, and other computer proof assistants.(no content)Type theory is an active area of research, one direction being the development of homotopy type theory.(no content)Much of the current research into type theory is driven by proof checkers, interactive proof assistants, and automated theorem provers.

Links: [{"title":"Lattice (order) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(order)"},{"title":"Lattice (group) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(group)"},{"title":"Lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice"},{"title":"Lattice (discrete subgroup) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(discrete_subgroup)"},{"title":"Lattice multiplication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_multiplication"},{"title":"E6 (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E6_(mathematics)"},{"title":"G2 (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G2_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Dual lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_lattice"},{"title":"Modular lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_lattice"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reference desk/Archives/Mathematics/2006 December 2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk/Archives/Mathematics/2006_December_2"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of lattice mathematics:

## Main Meanings of Lattice in Mathematics

A lattice is an abstract structure studied in the mathematical subdisciplines of order theory and abstract algebra. The term "lattice" has several important meanings in mathematics:

### Lattice (Order Theory)

A lattice consists of a partially ordered set in which every pair of elements has a unique supremum (also called a least upper bound or join) and a unique infimum (also called a greatest lower bound or meet).(no content)The sub-field of abstract algebra that studies lattices is called lattice theory.

### Lattice (Geometric)

In geometry and group theory, a lattice in the real coordinate space is a discrete set where coordinate-wise addition or subtraction of two points in the lattice produces another lattice point.(no content)One of the simplest examples of a lattice is the square lattice, which consists of all points in the plane whose coordinates are both integers, and its higher-dimensional analogues the integer lattices.

### Lattice (Discrete Subgroup)

In Lie theory and related areas of mathematics, a lattice in a locally compact group is a discrete subgroup with the property that the quotient space has finite invariant measure.

## Applications

Dual lattices have many applications inside of lattice theory, theoretical computer science, cryptography and mathematics more broadly. For instance, it is used in the statement of the Poisson summation formula, transference theorems provide connections between the geometry of a lattice and that of its dual, and many lattice algorithms exploit the dual lattice.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of lattice mathematics:

## Main Meanings of Lattice in Mathematics

A lattice is an abstract structure studied in the mathematical subdisciplines of order theory and abstract algebra. The term "lattice" has several important meanings in mathematics:

### Lattice (Order Theory)

A lattice consists of a partially ordered set in which every pair of elements has a unique supremum (also called a least upper bound or join) and a unique infimum (also called a greatest lower bound or meet).(no content)The sub-field of abstract algebra that studies lattices is called lattice theory.

### Lattice (Geometric)

In geometry and group theory, a lattice in the real coordinate space is a discrete set where coordinate-wise addition or subtraction of two points in the lattice produces another lattice point.(no content)One of the simplest examples of a lattice is the square lattice, which consists of all points in the plane whose coordinates are both integers, and its higher-dimensional analogues the integer lattices.

### Lattice (Discrete Subgroup)

In Lie theory and related areas of mathematics, a lattice in a locally compact group is a discrete subgroup with the property that the quotient space has finite invariant measure.

## Applications

Dual lattices have many applications inside of lattice theory, theoretical computer science, cryptography and mathematics more broadly. For instance, it is used in the statement of the Poisson summation formula, transference theorems provide connections between the geometry of a lattice and that of its dual, and many lattice algorithms exploit the dual lattice.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about proof theory:

## Overview

Proof theory is a major branch of mathematical logic and theoretical computer science within which proofs are treated as formal mathematical objects, facilitating their analysis by mathematical techniques. More specifically, proof theory is the study of formalized arguments.

## Key Characteristics

Proofs are typically presented as inductively defined data structures such as lists, boxed lists, or trees, which are constructed according to the axioms and rules of inference of a given logical system.(no content)Proof theory is syntactic in nature, in contrast to model theory, which issemantic in nature.

## Major Areas

Some of the major areas of proof theory include structural proof theory, ordinal analysis, provability logic, proof-theoretic semantics, reverse mathematics, proof mining, automated theorem proving, and proof complexity.(no content)Much research also focuses on applications in computer science, linguistics, and philosophy.

## Historical Development

Stanisław Jaśkowski (1929) and Gerhard Gentzen (1934) independently provided calculi of natural deduction, with Gentzen's approach introducing the idea of symmetry between the grounds for asserting propositions, expressed in introduction rules, and the consequences of accepting propositions in the elimination rules.(no content)Together, the presentation of natural deduction and the sequent calculus introduced the fundamental idea of analytic proof to proof theory.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the axiom of reducibility:

## Definition

The axiom of reducibility states that any truth function (propositional function) can be expressed by a formally equivalent predicative truth function.

## Historical Context

It made its first appearance in Bertrand Russell's (1908) Mathematical logic as based on the theory of types.(no content)By 1908, Russell arrived at a ramified theory of types together with an axiom of reducibility, both of which appeared in Whitehead and Russell's Principia Mathematica published in 1910, 1912, and 1913.

## Purpose and Motivation

Russell and Whitehead found it impossible to develop mathematics while maintaining the difference between predicative and non-predicative functions, so they introduced the axiom of reducibility, saying that for every non-predicative function there is a predicative function taking the same values.

## Impact on Type Theory

In practice this axiom essentially means that the elements of type (τ₁,...,τₘ|σ₁,...,σₙ) can be identified with the elements of type (τ₁,...,τₘ), which causes the hierarchy of ramified types to collapse down to simple type theory.

## Later Developments

In his 1914 A simplification of the logic of relations, Norbert Wiener removed the need for the axiom of reducibility as applied to relations between two variables by introducing a way to express a relation as a set of ordered pairs.

Web search results for query: "distributive lattice"

Links: [{"title":"Distributive lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributive_lattice"},{"title":"Completely distributive lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Completely_distributive_lattice"},{"title":"Birkhoff's representation theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birkhoff's_representation_theorem"},{"title":"Distributivity (order theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributivity_(order_theory)"},{"title":"Semilattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semilattice"},{"title":"Modular lattice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_lattice"},{"title":"Lattice (order) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(order)"},{"title":"Antimatroid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antimatroid"},{"title":"Duality theory for distributive lattices - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_theory_for_distributive_lattices"},{"title":"Congruence lattice problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congruence_lattice_problem"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about distributive lattices:

## Definition

A distributive lattice is a lattice in which the operations of join and meet distribute over each other.(no content)The prototypical examples of such structures are collections of sets for which the lattice operations can be given by set union and intersection.

## Key Characteristics

A lattice is distributive if and only if none of its sublattices is isomorphic to M3 or N5; a sublattice is a subset that is closed under the meet and join operations of the original lattice.(no content)The simplest non-distributive lattices are M3, the "diamond lattice", and N5, the "pentagon lattice".

## Examples

The main example for distributive lattices are lattices of sets, where join and meet are given by the usual set-theoretic operations. Other examples include:

- Every Boolean algebra is a distributive lattice.
- Every Heyting algebra is a distributive lattice. Especially this includes all locales and hence all open set lattices of topological spaces.
- Every totally ordered set is a distributive lattice with max as join and min as meet.
- The natural numbers form a (conditionally complete) distributive lattice by taking the greatest common divisor as meet and the least common multiple as join.

## Representation

Birkhoff's representation theorem for distributive lattices states that the elements of any finite distributive lattice can be represented as finite sets, in such a way that the lattice operations correspond to unions and intersections of sets.

The main example for distributive lattices are lattices of sets, where join and meet are given by the usual set-theoretic operations. Other examples include:

- Every Boolean algebra is a distributive lattice.
- Every Heyting algebra is a distributive lattice. Especially this includes all locales and hence all open set lattices of topological spaces.
- Every totally ordered set is a distributive lattice with max as join and min as meet.
- The natural numbers form a (conditionally complete) distributive lattice by taking the greatest common divisor as meet and the least common multiple as join.

## Representation

Birkhoff's representation theorem for distributive lattices states that the elements of any finite distributive lattice can be represented as finite sets, in such a way that the lattice operations correspond to unions and intersections of sets.

Web search results for query: "consistency proof mathematics logic"

Links: [{"title":"Consistency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consistency"},{"title":"Gentzen's consistency proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gentzen's_consistency_proof"},{"title":"Mathematical logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_logic"},{"title":"Gödel's incompleteness theorems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%B6del's_incompleteness_theorems"},{"title":"Equiconsistency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equiconsistency"},{"title":"Hilbert's second problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert's_second_problem"},{"title":"Axiomatic system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axiomatic_system"},{"title":"ω-consistent theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%CE%A9-consistent_theory"},{"title":"Mathematical proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_Proof"},{"title":"Gödel's completeness theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%B6del's_completeness_theorem"}]

Here are the search results for "consistency proof mathematics logic":

## Key Findings

**Definition and Overview**

A consistency proof is a mathematical proof that a particular theory is consistent.(no content)In deductive logic, a consistent theory is one that does not lead to a logical contradiction.

**Historical Context**

The early development of mathematical proof theory was driven by the desire to provide finitary consistency proofs for all of mathematics as part of Hilbert's program. However, Hilbert's program was strongly impacted by the incompleteness theorems, which showed that sufficiently strong proof theories cannot prove their consistency (provided that they are consistent).

**Methods and Approaches**

Although consistency can be proved using model theory, it is often done in a purely syntactical way, without any need to reference some model of the logic. Additionally, cut-elimination (or equivalently the normalization of the underlying calculus if there is one) implies the consistency of the calculus: since there is no cut-free proof of falsity, there is no contradiction in general.

**Gentzen's Consistency Proof**

Gentzen's consistency proof is a result of proof theory in mathematical logic, published by Gerhard Gentzen in 1936.(no content)Gentzen's theory obtained by adding quantifier-free transfinite induction to primitive recursive arithmetic proves the consistency of first-order Peano arithmetic (PA).

**Gödel's Incompleteness Theorems Impact**

Gödel's incompleteness theorem established the impossibility of providing a consistency proof of arithmetic within any formal theory of arithmetic.(no content)However, this leaves open the possibility of consistency proofs that cannot be formalized within the system they consider. Gentzen proved the consistency of arithmetic using a finitistic system together with a principle of transfinite induction.

Links: [{"title":"Sequent calculus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequent_calculus"},{"title":"Sequent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequent"},{"title":"Nested sequent calculus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nested_sequent_calculus"},{"title":"Talk:Sequent calculus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Sequent_calculus"},{"title":"Cut-elimination theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cut-elimination_theorem"},{"title":"Cut rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cut_rule"},{"title":"Talk:Structural proof theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Structural_proof_theory"},{"title":"Focused proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focused_proof"},{"title":"Modus ponens - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modus_ponens"},{"title":"Hypersequent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypersequent"}]

Here's what I found about sequent calculus:

## Overview

Sequent calculus is a style of formal logical argumentation in which every line of a proof is a conditional tautology (called a sequent by Gerhard Gentzen) instead of an unconditional tautology.(no content)Each conditional tautology is inferred from other conditional tautologies according to rules and procedures of inference, giving a better approximation to the natural style of deduction used by mathematicians than David Hilbert's earlier style of formal logic.

## Key Concepts

In mathematical logic, a sequent is a very general kind of conditional assertion that may have any number of condition formulas (called "antecedents") and any number of asserted formulas (called "succedents" or "consequents"). A sequent is understood to mean that if all of the antecedent conditions are true, then at least one of the consequent formulas is true.

## Historical Development

The first sequent calculi systems, LK and LJ, were introduced in 1934/1935 by Gerhard Gentzen as a tool for studying natural deduction in first-order logic (in classical and intuitionistic versions, respectively).(no content)Gentzen's so-called "Main Theorem" (Hauptsatz) about LK and LJ was the cut-elimination theorem, a result with far-reaching meta-theoretic consequences, including consistency.

## Applications

Natural deduction systems are more suited to practical theorem-proving, while sequent calculus systems are more suited to theoretical analysis.

Web search results for query: "infinitary logic"

Links: [{"title":"Infinitary logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinitary_logic"},{"title":"Infinite-valued logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite-valued_logic"},{"title":"Finitary - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finitary"},{"title":"First-order logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-order_logic"},{"title":"Łukasiewicz logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C5%81ukasiewicz_logic"},{"title":"Infinite expression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_expression"},{"title":"Ω-logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%CE%A9-logic"},{"title":"Rule of inference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rules_of_logic"},{"title":"Löwenheim–Skolem theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Löwenheim–Skolem_theorem"},{"title":"Glossary of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about infinitary logic:

## Definition

An infinitary logic is a logic that allows infinitely long statements and/or infinitely long proofs.(no content)The concept was introduced by Zermelo in the 1930s.

## Key Properties

Some infinitary logics may have different properties from those of standard first-order logic, and in particular, infinitary logics may fail to be compact or complete.(no content)Many extensions of first-order logic, including infinitary logics and higher-order logics, are more expressive in the sense that they do permit categorical axiomatizations of the natural numbers or real numbers.

## Common Forms

The most commonly studied infinitary logics are denoted Lαβ, where α and β are each either cardinal numbers or the symbol ∞. In this notation, ordinary first-order logic is Lωω.(no content)In the logic L∞ω, arbitrary conjunctions or disjunctions are allowed when building formulas, and there is an unlimited supply of variables. For example, Lω1ω permits countable conjunctions and disjunctions.

## Applications

Many theories, including Peano arithmetic, which cannot be properly axiomatised in finitary logic, can be in a suitable infinitary logic. Other examples include the theories of non-archimedean fields and torsion-free groups.

Based on the search results, here's information about infinitary logic:

## Definition

An infinitary logic is a logic that allows infinitely long statements and/or infinitely long proofs.(no content)The concept was introduced by Zermelo in the 1930s.

## Key Properties

Some infinitary logics may have different properties from those of standard first-order logic, and in particular, infinitary logics may fail to be compact or complete.(no content)Many extensions of first-order logic, including infinitary logics and higher-order logics, are more expressive in the sense that they do permit categorical axiomatizations of the natural numbers or real numbers.

## Common Forms

The most commonly studied infinitary logics are denoted Lαβ, where α and β are each either cardinal numbers or the symbol ∞. In this notation, ordinary first-order logic is Lωω.(no content)In the logic L∞ω, arbitrary conjunctions or disjunctions are allowed when building formulas, and there is an unlimited supply of variables. For example, Lω1ω permits countable conjunctions and disjunctions.

## Applications

Many theories, including Peano arithmetic, which cannot be properly axiomatised in finitary logic, can be in a suitable infinitary logic. Other examples include the theories of non-archimedean fields and torsion-free groups.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - This is a contribution paper because it proposes a new translation and introduction to Lorenzen's work, introduces novel proof methods, and presents new mathematical definitions as deductive calculi.

**Key Findings:**
- **15 triples** were extracted from the paper's title and abstract
- **11 concepts**, 2 methods, 1 task, and 1 tool were identified
- The paper demonstrates a strong foundation in proof theory, type theory, and lattice theory

**Main Contributions:**
1. Novel cut elimination method using double induction (without ordinal assignment)
2. Constructive consistency proof for ramified type theory without axiom of reducibility
3. Definitions of mathematical structures (semilattice, distributive lattice, Boolean lattice) as deductive calculi
4. Application of preorder-theoretic methods for consistency proofs

**Technologies & Methodologies Used:**
- Free lattices, Proof theory, Type theory, Mathematical induction, Sequent calculus, Infinitary logic, and more

All validation checks passed successfully! The triples_output.json file is now complete with all required metadata including Wikipedia URLs for each entity.
